elements.content: Two layered zincophosphites constructed from an emissive linker molecule were prepared. The ligand connects zincophosphite chains or clusters to form two distinct two-dimensional hybrid frameworks in two compounds. The coordinating effect of an organic ligand to Zn centers increases the rigidity and results in room temperature phosphorescence.
elements.clean_text: Two layered zincophosphites constructed from an emissive linker molecule were prepared. The ligand connects zincophosphite chains or clusters to form two distinct two-dimensional hybrid frameworks in two compounds. The coordinating effect of an organic ligand to Zn centers increases the rigidity and results in room temperature phosphorescence.

elements.content:
Two layered hybrid zincophosphites with different structures and room temperature phosphorescent properties are presented.

Phosphorescent materials have been the subject of continuous interest in recent years because of their potential values in biological imaging, multimode anticounterfeiting, photodynamic therapy, etc. Phosphorescence originating from radiative decay of a triplet excited state usually occurs at low temperatures (e.g., 77 K) or in an inert atmosphere accompanied by relatively low decay time, which seriously restricts the application of such materials. Therefore, continuous efforts have been made to exploit long-lived room temperature phosphorescent (RTP) materials. Early investigated RTP materials mainly focus on complexes containing metals with strong spin–orbital coupling (SCO) like iridium and platinum. Intersystem crossing from a single excited state to a triplet excited state driven by SCO provides extra freedom to fabricate targeted materials. However, such RTP materials usually feature high cost, low decay time (tens of microseconds), and flexibility. Most recently, pure organic RTP materials are booming because of their variety and good processability. Also, several feasible strategies, such as crystallization, H-aggregation, binary copolymerization, and host–guest, have been proposed to tune and promote the RTP properties. 4-Chlorobenzoyldibenzothiophene in the crystalline state, for instance, can emit white room temperature phosphorescence derived from the intrasystem mixing of high- and low-lying triplet states. By effectively stabilizing the triplet excitons through molecular H-aggregation, ultra-long-lived luminescence in different organic molecules can be realized by tailoring the molecular structures. Inorganic–organic hybrid frameworks constructed from inorganic moieties and organic ligands directed by crystal engineering strategies may bring new opportunities for the design and synthesis of RTP materials. Yang and Yan, for example, used coordination interaction to form metal–organic frameworks by integrating terephthalic acid with Zn ions and obtained the long-lived persistent room temperature phosphorescence. Hu et al. achieved unique multiple-colored (from cyan to red) RTP materials in a mixed-organic-cation perovskite system by molecular design.
elements.clean_text:
Two layered hybrid zincophosphites with different structures and room temperature phosphorescent properties are presented.

Phosphorescent materials have been the subject of continuous interest in recent years because of their potential values in biological imaging, multimode anticounterfeiting, photodynamic therapy, etc. Phosphorescence originating from radiative decay of a triplet excited state usually occurs at low temperatures (e.g., 77 K) or in an inert atmosphere accompanied by relatively low decay time, which seriously restricts the application of such materials. Therefore, continuous efforts have been made to exploit long-lived room temperature phosphorescent (RTP) materials. Early investigated RTP materials mainly focus on complexes containing metals with strong spin-orbital coupling (SCO) like iridium and platinum. Intersystem crossing from a single excited state to a triplet excited state driven by SCO provides extra freedom to fabricate targeted materials. However, such RTP materials usually feature high cost, low decay time (tens of microseconds), and flexibility. Most recently, pure organic RTP materials are booming because of their variety and good processability. Also, several feasible strategies, such as crystallization, H-aggregation, binary copolymerization, and host-guest, have been proposed to tune and promote the RTP properties. 4-Chlorobenzoyldibenzothiophene in the crystalline state, for instance, can emit white room temperature phosphorescence derived from the intrasystem mixing of high- and low-lying triplet states. By effectively stabilizing the triplet excitons through molecular H-aggregation, ultra-long-lived luminescence in different organic molecules can be realized by tailoring the molecular structures. Inorganic-organic hybrid frameworks constructed from inorganic moieties and organic ligands directed by crystal engineering strategies may bring new opportunities for the design and synthesis of RTP materials. Yang and Yan, for example, used coordination interaction to form metal-organic frameworks by integrating terephthalic acid with Zn ions and obtained the long-lived persistent room temperature phosphorescence. Hu et al. achieved unique multiple-colored (from cyan to red) RTP materials in a mixed-organic-cation perovskite system by molecular design.

elements.content: Hybrid metal phosphate/phosphites containing organic conjugated ligands have been well studied as an emerging fluorescent material, but research on RTP materials of this class remains quite limited. It has been demonstrated that molecule excited states with mixed (π,π*) and (n,π*) configurations in appropriate proportions hold promise to produce RTP materials. Thus, 1,3,5-tris­(1-imidazolyl)­benzene (tib for short) with conjugated six-membered benzene units and five-membered imidazole units is a promising candidate for the construction of RTP materials. We have explored the Zn­(H3PO3)­(tib) system to fabricate potential hybrid RTP phosphites and obtained the first three-dimensional (3D) hybrid zincophosphite framework QDU-5 with RTP features. From the aspect of molecular-level and crystal engineering, low-dimensional hybrid structures may show phosphorescent performances different from those of 3D structures. For a better understanding of the potential structure–phosphorescence relationship, herein we present two two-dimensional (2D) hybrid frameworks, [Zn3(HPO3)3(tib)]·2H2O (QDU-7) and [Zn3(HPO3)2(tib)2]·2NO3 (QDU-8), with RTP properties. QDU-7 is solvothermally synthesized from ZnO, H3PO3, tib, N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), and water at 145 °C for 7 days and features a hybrid layer formed by a tib ligand pillaring zincophosphite chains. QDU-8 is synthesized from Zn­(NO3)2, H3PO3, tib, DMF, and water at 145 °C for 1 day and presents a hybrid layer formed by a tib ligand directly connecting zincophosphite clusters. Notably, QDU-7 and QDU-8 display interesting RTP properties with different lifetimes.
elements.clean_text: Hybrid metal phosphate/phosphites containing organic conjugated ligands have been well studied as an emerging fluorescent material, but research on RTP materials of this class remains quite limited. It has been demonstrated that molecule excited states with mixed (π,π*) and (n,π*) configurations in appropriate proportions hold promise to produce RTP materials. Thus, 1,3,5-tris(1-imidazolyl)benzene (tib for short) with conjugated six-membered benzene units and five-membered imidazole units is a promising candidate for the construction of RTP materials. We have explored the Zn(H3PO3)(tib) system to fabricate potential hybrid RTP phosphites and obtained the first three-dimensional (3D) hybrid zincophosphite framework QDU-5 with RTP features. From the aspect of molecular-level and crystal engineering, low-dimensional hybrid structures may show phosphorescent performances different from those of 3D structures. For a better understanding of the potential structure-phosphorescence relationship, herein we present two two-dimensional (2D) hybrid frameworks, [Zn3(HPO3)3(tib)]⋅2H2O (QDU-7) and [Zn3(HPO3)2(tib)2]⋅2NO3 (QDU-8), with RTP properties. QDU-7 is solvothermally synthesized from ZnO, H3PO3, tib, N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), and water at 145 °C for 7 days and features a hybrid layer formed by a tib ligand pillaring zincophosphite chains. QDU-8 is synthesized from Zn(NO3)2, H3PO3, tib, DMF, and water at 145 °C for 1 day and presents a hybrid layer formed by a tib ligand directly connecting zincophosphite clusters. Notably, QDU-7 and QDU-8 display interesting RTP properties with different lifetimes.

elements.content: QDU-7 crystallizes in the P1̅ space group (No. 2; Table S1). The asymmetric unit possesses three Zn ions, three phosphite groups, one tib molecule, and two free water molecules. The tib ligands display the η1:η1:η1:μ3 mode to link three Zn2+ ions with N–Zn bond lengths in the scope of 1.983(8)–2.011(9) Å (a and Table S2). HPO3 2– ligands have the η1:η1:η1:μ3 mode to connect three Zn2+ ions with O–Zn bond lengths between 1.884(7) and 1.961(6) Å (a and Table S2). All tetracoordinate Zn atoms feature a {NO3} donor set, defined by three O atoms from phosphite and one N atom from tib (a and Table S2). The bond angles of O–Zn–O and O–Zn–N are between 98.6(4) and 117.4(3)°. The phosphite moieties bridge the Zn2+ ions to form neutral inorganic zincophosphite chains as subunits (b), which are further connected by the neutral organic tib ligand to generate the final inorganic–organic hybrid layer (c). The guest water molecules locate in the interlayer voids and interact with the hybrid layer via hydrogen bonds. To better understand the structural characteristics, topological analysis was conducted. The μ3-bridging ligands (tib and phosphite) and tetracoordinate Zn atoms could be viewed as 3- and 4-connected nodes, respectively. On the basis of this simplification, the hybrid layer could be depicted as a 3,4-connected seven-nodal net with a (42·6·82·10)­(42·62·8·10)­(42·62·82)­(42·6)3(6·82) point symbol calculated by TOPOS (d).
elements.clean_text: QDU-7 crystallizes in the P1̅ space group (No. 2; Table S1). The asymmetric unit possesses three Zn ions, three phosphite groups, one tib molecule, and two free water molecules. The tib ligands display the η1:η1:η1:μ3 mode to link three Zn2+ ions with N-Zn bond lengths in the scope of 1.983(8)-2.011(9) Å (a and Table S2). HPO3 2- ligands have the η1:η1:η1:μ3 mode to connect three Zn2+ ions with O-Zn bond lengths between 1.884(7) and 1.961(6) Å (a and Table S2). All tetracoordinate Zn atoms feature a {NO3} donor set, defined by three O atoms from phosphite and one N atom from tib (a and Table S2). The bond angles of O-Zn-O and O-Zn-N are between 98.6(4) and 117.4(3)°. The phosphite moieties bridge the Zn2+ ions to form neutral inorganic zincophosphite chains as subunits (b), which are further connected by the neutral organic tib ligand to generate the final inorganic-organic hybrid layer (c). The guest water molecules locate in the interlayer voids and interact with the hybrid layer via hydrogen bonds. To better understand the structural characteristics, topological analysis was conducted. The μ3-bridging ligands (tib and phosphite) and tetracoordinate Zn atoms could be viewed as 3- and 4-connected nodes, respectively. On the basis of this simplification, the hybrid layer could be depicted as a 3,4-connected seven-nodal net with a (42⋅6⋅82⋅10)(42⋅62⋅8⋅10)(42⋅62⋅82)(42⋅6)3(6⋅82) point symbol calculated by TOPOS (d).

elements.content: (a) Coordination mode of Zn atoms and ligands in QDU-7. (b) One-dimensional zincophosphite chain. (c) Inorganic–organic hybrid zincophosphite layer. (d) Topology of QDU-7.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination mode of Zn atoms and ligands in QDU-7. (b) One-dimensional zincophosphite chain. (c) Inorganic-organic hybrid zincophosphite layer. (d) Topology of QDU-7.

elements.content: The space group of QDU-8 is also P1̅ (No. 2). Its asymmetric unit has two HPO3 2– groups, three Zn ions, two tib ligands, and two free NO3 – anions. The tib ligands coordinate to three Zn2+ ions, exhibiting the η1:η1:η1:μ3 mode (a). The N–Zn bond lengths are in the range of 1.901(13)–2.052(12) Å (Table S3). The HPO3 2– ligands bridge three Zn2+ ions with the η1:η1:η1:μ3 mode (a). The O–Zn bond lengths are between 1.876(8) and 2.043(12) Å (Table S3). The Zn atoms are all in the [ZnN2O2] tetrahedral coordination accomplished by two N atoms from tib and two O atoms from phosphite (a). The bond angles of N–Zn–N, N–Zn–O, and O–Zn–O are between 85.2(6) and 137.8(6)°. Two phosphite groups bridge three Zn ions to form trinuclear [Zn3(HPO3)2]2+ subunits (b), which are further connected by six N atoms of tib to generate a hybrid positive layer (c). The positive charge of the hybrid layers is balanced by a free NO3 – anion. The presence of NO3 – has been well-confirmed by comparing the IR plots of NaNO3, tib, H3PO3, and QDU-8 (Figure S3). Neighboring hybrid layers are packed in the [−ABAB−] modes (d). From the point of topological analysis, the trinuclear [Zn3(HPO3)2]2+ units and tib ligands could be treated as 6- and 3-connected nodes, respectively. The hybrid layer could be simplified as a 3,6-connected two-nodal net with a (43)2(46·66·83) point symbol calculated by TOPOS (Figure S4).
elements.clean_text: The space group of QDU-8 is also P1̅ (No. 2). Its asymmetric unit has two HPO3 2- groups, three Zn ions, two tib ligands, and two free NO3 - anions. The tib ligands coordinate to three Zn2+ ions, exhibiting the η1:η1:η1:μ3 mode (a). The N-Zn bond lengths are in the range of 1.901(13)-2.052(12) Å (Table S3). The HPO3 2- ligands bridge three Zn2+ ions with the η1:η1:η1:μ3 mode (a). The O-Zn bond lengths are between 1.876(8) and 2.043(12) Å (Table S3). The Zn atoms are all in the [ZnN2O2] tetrahedral coordination accomplished by two N atoms from tib and two O atoms from phosphite (a). The bond angles of N-Zn-N, N-Zn-O, and O-Zn-O are between 85.2(6) and 137.8(6)°. Two phosphite groups bridge three Zn ions to form trinuclear [Zn3(HPO3)2]2+ subunits (b), which are further connected by six N atoms of tib to generate a hybrid positive layer (c). The positive charge of the hybrid layers is balanced by a free NO3 - anion. The presence of NO3 - has been well-confirmed by comparing the IR plots of NaNO3, tib, H3PO3, and QDU-8 (Figure S3). Neighboring hybrid layers are packed in the [-ABAB-] modes (d). From the point of topological analysis, the trinuclear [Zn3(HPO3)2]2+ units and tib ligands could be treated as 6- and 3-connected nodes, respectively. The hybrid layer could be simplified as a 3,6-connected two-nodal net with a (43)2(46⋅66⋅83) point symbol calculated by TOPOS (Figure S4).

elements.content: (a) Coordination mode of Zn atoms and ligands in QDU-8. (b) Trinuclear [Zn3(HPO3)2]2+ subunits connected by six imidazole moieties. (c) Single hybrid layer of QDU-8. (d) Packing layer of QDU-8.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Coordination mode of Zn atoms and ligands in QDU-8. (b) Trinuclear [Zn3(HPO3)2]2+ subunits connected by six imidazole moieties. (c) Single hybrid layer of QDU-8. (d) Packing layer of QDU-8.

elements.content: Although the framework constituents of QDU-7 and QDU-8 are the same (tib, HPO3 2– groups, and Zn2+ ions), they feature a distinct network, which is mainly attributable to the distinct connecting modes between organic tib moieties and inorganic supramolecular building blocks (SBBs). The SBBs are neutral zincophosphite chains and cationic trinuclear [Zn3(HPO3)2]2+ clusters for QDU-7 and QDU-8, respectively. The neutral organic tib ligands display the η1:η1:η1:μ3 mode to link the corresponding inorganic SBBs to form the resultant neutral layer for QDU-7 and the cationic layer for QDU-8. The guests are free water and NO3 – anions for QDU-7 and QDU-8, respectively.
elements.clean_text: Although the framework constituents of QDU-7 and QDU-8 are the same (tib, HPO3 2- groups, and Zn2+ ions), they feature a distinct network, which is mainly attributable to the distinct connecting modes between organic tib moieties and inorganic supramolecular building blocks (SBBs). The SBBs are neutral zincophosphite chains and cationic trinuclear [Zn3(HPO3)2]2+ clusters for QDU-7 and QDU-8, respectively. The neutral organic tib ligands display the η1:η1:η1:μ3 mode to link the corresponding inorganic SBBs to form the resultant neutral layer for QDU-7 and the cationic layer for QDU-8. The guests are free water and NO3 - anions for QDU-7 and QDU-8, respectively.

elements.content: shows the photoluminescence (PL) emission and decay properties of QDU-7 and QDU-8 at 300 K in air. For QDU-7, the prompt PL emission shows a peak at 380 nm when excited by 340 nm, and the crystal appears to be blue. The delayed spectrum is obtained after the excitation source is taken off for 1 ms, and it shows an emission at 480 nm. The crystal presents a turquoise afterglow (a). A time-resolved decay curve was recorded, and the fitting result shows that it has a lifetime of 28.6 ms at room temperature (b). For QDU-8, however, the case is a little different. Its prompt emission presents one peak at 370 nm when excited by 310 nm, and the crystal appears to be nearly white. The delayed spectrum shows a peak at 510 nm, and the afterglow of the crystal becomes green-yellow (c). A time-resolved decay curve of QDU-8 gives a lifetime of 116 ms (d). Furthermore, the effects of temperature on the PL of two compounds have also been investigated. Figure S5 shows the temperature-dependent luminescent emission spectra of QDU-7 and QDU-8. The PL intensity of both compounds increases with decrease temperature from 503 to 83 K due to the suppression of nonradiative decay. The long-wavelength emission band at around 470 nm is dramatically enhanced when the temperature decreases below 200 K, which corresponds to the phosphorescent emission of QDU-7 and QDU-8. In addition, the quantum yields (QYs) are 2.15% and 7.54% respectively for QDU-7 and QDU-8. The present RTP may benefit from both the intrinsic configuration of the organic ligand and its participation in the formation of the hybrid framework. That is, the lone-pair electrons of N atoms in the tib ligand trigger SCO and promote efficient triplet exciton, while immobilization of tib in the resultant hybrid stabilizes the triplet excitons and suppresses the nonradiative decay.

For QDU-7, the prompt PL emission shows a peak at 380 nm when excited by 340 nm, and the crystal appears to be blue. The delayed spectrum is obtained after the excitation source is taken off for 1 ms, and it shows an emission at 480 nm. The crystal presents a turquoise afterglow (a). A time-resolved decay curve was recorded, and the fitting result shows that it has a lifetime of 28.6 ms at room temperature (b). For QDU-8, however, the case is a little different. Its prompt emission presents one peak at 370 nm when excited by 310 nm, and the crystal appears to be nearly white. The delayed spectrum shows a peak at 510 nm, and the afterglow of the crystal becomes green-yellow (c). A time-resolved decay curve of QDU-8 gives a lifetime of 116 ms (d). Furthermore, the effects of temperature on the PL of two compounds have also been investigated. Figure S5 shows the temperature-dependent luminescent emission spectra of QDU-7 and QDU-8. The PL intensity of both compounds increases with decrease temperature from 503 to 83 K due to the suppression of nonradiative decay. The long-wavelength emission band at around 470 nm is dramatically enhanced when the temperature decreases below 200 K, which corresponds to the phosphorescent emission of QDU-7 and QDU-8. In addition, the quantum yields (QYs) are 2.15% and 7.54% respectively for QDU-7 and QDU-8. The present RTP may benefit from both the intrinsic configuration of the organic ligand and its participation in the formation of the hybrid framework. That is, the lone-pair electrons of N atoms in the tib ligand trigger SCO and promote efficient triplet exciton, while immobilization of tib in the resultant hybrid stabilizes the triplet excitons and suppresses the nonradiative decay.

elements.content: (a and c) Prompt and delayed PL emission spectra of QDU-7 and QDU-8. The fluorescent and phosphorescent photographs taken under ambient conditions are shown in the insets. The excitation source is 302 nm. (b and d) PL decay and fit curves obtained at 300 K of QDU-7 and QDU-8.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a and c) Prompt and delayed PL emission spectra of QDU-7 and QDU-8. The fluorescent and phosphorescent photographs taken under ambient conditions are shown in the insets. The excitation source is 302 nm. (b and d) PL decay and fit curves obtained at 300 K of QDU-7 and QDU-8.

elements.content: The differences in the photophysical properties between QDU-7 and QDU-8 may be related to the ligand environments in the crystalline structures. The network constituents of 2D QDU-7 and the reported 3D QDU-6 are nearly identical (neutral zincophosphite chain and tib); however, their phosphorescent behaviors are different in terms of the lifetime and QY, which indicates the presence of structure-dependent phosphorescence in the Zn­(HPO3)­(tib) system. Thus, phosphorescence of tib-modified zincophosphite is highly dependent on the specific geometrical configuration (such as the dihedral angles between the imidazole and central benzene groups) of the tib moiety in the two structures. The distinct phosphorescent behavior of QDU-7 and QDU-8 is mainly derived from the distinct geometrical configuration of tib in the resultant structure.
elements.clean_text: The differences in the photophysical properties between QDU-7 and QDU-8 may be related to the ligand environments in the crystalline structures. The network constituents of 2D QDU-7 and the reported 3D QDU-6 are nearly identical (neutral zincophosphite chain and tib); however, their phosphorescent behaviors are different in terms of the lifetime and QY, which indicates the presence of structure-dependent phosphorescence in the Zn(HPO3)(tib) system. Thus, phosphorescence of tib-modified zincophosphite is highly dependent on the specific geometrical configuration (such as the dihedral angles between the imidazole and central benzene groups) of the tib moiety in the two structures. The distinct phosphorescent behavior of QDU-7 and QDU-8 is mainly derived from the distinct geometrical configuration of tib in the resultant structure.

elements.content: In conclusion, two novel inorganic–organic hybrid 2D zinc phosphite frameworks, QDU-7 and QDU-8, were synthesized, and the PL properties based on the tripodal imidazole ligand were investigated. They feature different subunits and hybrid patterns, which results in various fluorescent and phosphorescent colors, lifetimes, and QYs under ambient conditions. The RTP materials of QDU-7 and QDU-8 profit from the use of an N-containing organic ligand and the formation of the hybrid framework. This work promotes the development of metal phosphite/phosphate as phosphors through the design of hybrid materials in which functional organic molecules, such as polydentate N/O-containing ligands, are introduced.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, two novel inorganic-organic hybrid 2D zinc phosphite frameworks, QDU-7 and QDU-8, were synthesized, and the PL properties based on the tripodal imidazole ligand were investigated. They feature different subunits and hybrid patterns, which results in various fluorescent and phosphorescent colors, lifetimes, and QYs under ambient conditions. The RTP materials of QDU-7 and QDU-8 profit from the use of an N-containing organic ligand and the formation of the hybrid framework. This work promotes the development of metal phosphite/phosphate as phosphors through the design of hybrid materials in which functional organic molecules, such as polydentate N/O-containing ligands, are introduced.

metadata.title: Layered Hybrid Zincophosphites for Room Temperature Phosphorescent Emission
